body:
Hello there,

Did you define remote for local file system also?

Regards,
Zeshan
On Mar 23, 2015 9:08 AM, "Khurshid Alam" notifications@github.com wrote:

> copy or sync command does _NOT_ work for symlink folders when syncing to
> Google Drive. It would be nice if rclone can follow symlinks.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/ncw/rclone/issues/40.

> Did you define remote for local file system also?

What did you mean by that?

The command I used is something like this (on Ubuntu 14.04):
`rclone sync /home/$user/$Test drive:Documents/$Test`

Here the folder `$Test` consists several symlinks (soft links) to which are actually located on different partition. Rclone exits without following symlinks. Am I missing something?

Sorry, I mean using rclone config command. There is a command line wizard.

rclone config

Regards,
Zeshan
On Mar 23, 2015 9:53 AM, "Khurshid Alam" notifications@github.com wrote:

> Did you define remote for local file system also?
> 
> What did you mean by that?
> 
> The command I used is something like this (on Ubuntu 14.04):
> rclone sync /home/$user/$Test drive:Documents/$Test. Here the folder $Test
> consists several symlinks to folders on different partition. Rclone exits
> without following symlinks. Am I missing something?
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/ncw/rclone/issues/40#issuecomment-85005629.

> Sorry, I mean using rclone config command. There is a command line wizard
> rclone config

Yes. That was already done.

Will have to wait for Nick. Sorry, I wasn't much help.

Regards,
Zeshan
On Mar 23, 2015 10:07 AM, "Khurshid Alam" notifications@github.com wrote:

> Sorry, I mean using rclone config command. There is a command line wizard
> rclone config
> 
> Yes. That was already done.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/ncw/rclone/issues/40#issuecomment-85012937.

@khurshid-alam rclone (taking the lead from rsync) deliberately doesn't follow symlinks as doing so then opens it up to recursive directory loops and other nasty things like that

I could implement this flag (from the rsync man page)

```
   -L, --copy-links
          When symlinks are encountered, the item that they point to  (the
          referent) is copied, rather than ignoring the symlink
```

However rclone will never be able to copy symlinks themselves (you can't store these on object storage systems), so it will work like rsync with the `-L` flag and without the `-K` flag.

The `-L` flag would only work on local filesystems.

Eg if your source directory looks like this

```
   root
      link -> /path/to/dir

   /path/to/dir
      file one
      file two
```

The destination would end up looking like this

```
  root
    link
        file one
        file two
```

Does that match your expectations?

Possibly this should be the default behaviour of rclone - I'm not sure.

The reverse sync needs some more thought - what if there is a symlink in the local fs when we are copying from remote to local:.  Do we

```
* Follow it
* Delete it and create the file/directory directly
* Other
```

> However rclone will never be able to copy symlinks themselves (you can't store these on object storage systems), so it will work like rsync with the -L flag and without the -K flag.
> 
> The -L flag would only work on local filesystems.

That's is fine with me. I intend to use it only for Local-->Remote sync.

> The destination would end up looking like this
> 
> ```
> root
>     link
>         file one
>         file two
> ```
> 
> Does that match your expectations?

Yes it is! I usually rename my symlinks folders to match the actual ones. This is perfect for me.

I have a slightly different spin on this request.  I'd like a way to preserve symlinks in POSIX
filesystems when doing a copy/sync to (or from) object store.

in addition to a flag that follows links and copies the content of the linked target,
I'd like to see a flag that copies symlinks as "symlink object".

Since you can't represent a symlink in an object, you instead create a placeholder
object (lets call it an ".slink" object, that contains the metadata needed to re-create
the symlink when its copied out of the object store.

for example,  if a source directory contains
ls -l bazinga 
lrwxrwxrwx 1 skottie user 20 May 26 16:54 bazinga -> /some/symlinked/path

an object would be created in the destination object store called "bazinga.slink",
and inside that object would be the string "/some/symlinked/path" and anything else
needed to re-create the link on the target filesystem.

or something like that.

 -skottie

issue.title: Symlinked directories aren't getting copied

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
When some directory is a symlink (/my/symlink -> /some/real/dir), rclone ignores its contents.

This command does nothing:

```
rclone copy /my/symlink remote:backup
```

rclone should see the same files that 'ls' sees.

body: I would also be interested in this feature. I have several directories that have symlinks to other locations on external storage. It would be nice to have the rclone follow those links and copy the contents from those directories.

+1

Just need to be careful in case of **recursive symlink** that it gets copied only once.

Test example:

```
temp1/
  a1/
    b1/
       a2/ --> ../../a2/
       f1
  a2/
    b2/
       a1/ --> ../../a1/
       f2
  a3/ --> ../temp2/
temp2/
  f3
```

rsync will fails badly on this:

```
rsync -Lav temp1 temp1_clone
```

(note `temp1/a1/b1/a2/b2/a1/b1/a2/b2/a1/b1/a2/b2/` is valid and some directory traversal would happily loop there)

Expected copied files structure (without cycles):
- a1/b1/f1
- a2/b2/f2
- a3/f3

Expecting also warning/error messages.
See https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/gsutil/pull/325 for how this can be implemented in Python.

Please, be sure to keep both options. I'm actually requiring rclone to skip symlinks. Thank you :-)

If you want to keep symlinks on cloud hosting, maybe you could save the target path as a standard text file, with identical filename, and a special flag in metadatas when the provider supports metadatas.

It's not about keeping symlinks as cloud hosts usually don't allow symlinks. It's about mimicking `rsync -k` (and even better by handling circular references) so that all files can get copied (backed up). It's also an optional flag.
-L or --copy-links is not currently supported yet, isn't it?

Correct. In [that PR](https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/gsutil/pull/325) I've actually improved `-L` to detect, alert, and nicely handle circular references (rare but can happen and rsync is just having a kind of path overflow there).
I came here to recommend --copy-links. It's a must for my rsync's so hopefully the PR will get some attention.
Any updates on this?  I'm looking forward to a solution to this.
I'll try to get this done for v1.35
Has this feature been included yet?
@darylstyrk not yet - I haven't released v1.34 yet, this should be in v1.35.  I'll post a beta here in due course for people to try
